node.title: Rules that allowed Christian Porter not to disclose who gave him money should be changed, committee finds
node.alt: Christian Porter sitting on the frontbench in the House of Representatives
node.description: The rules that govern what gifts and donations politicians must disclose need to be fixed, a highly regarded bipartisan committee finds — though it says former attorney-general Christian Porter is not in breach of them.
node.content:
["Former attorney-general Christian Porter did not breach parliamentary rules by not disclosing who helped cover some of the legal fees he incurred during his defamation case against the ABC, a parliamentary committee has concluded.", "In September, Mr Porter updated his register of members' interests to show that a blind trust had made a \"part contribution\" to cover the costs of his lawyers, who filed a lawsuit against the public broadcaster.", "He refused repeated calls to outline who those donors were, and stepped down as attorney-general.", "At the time of his resignation, Mr Porter issued a lengthy statement defending his decision and insisted that he had always followed the rules.\u00a0", "\"Ultimately, I decided that if I have to make a choice between seeking to pressure the trust to break individuals' confidentiality in order to remain in cabinet, or alternatively forego my cabinet position, there is only one choice I could, in all conscience, make,\" he said in September.\u00a0", "Federal Labor asked the Committee of Privileges and Members' Interests to examine whether Mr Porter should have provided more details on the money he received.\u00a0", "The bipartisan committee concluded he did not breach parliamentary rules and it was his decision on whether to provide extra information to the register of members' interests.\u00a0", "\"The Committee concludes that the declaration by the Member for Pearce was consistent with his obligations under the Resolution on the Registration of Members' Interests,\" the committee's report said.\u00a0", "\"However, the Committee considers all Members should seek to provide the greatest level of transparency in the disclosure of the source of gifts received by them.\"", "", "
Privileges committee chair Russell Broadbent resigned from his position as he released the report, taking responsibility for a leak to the press overnight.(ABC News: Luke Stephenson)
", "The committee did acknowledge that the current arrangements were \"inadequate\" and said it was looking to change the process so that politicians provided more detailed information about gifts and donations.", "\"The Committee considers that additional detail within the requirements of the Register would assist Members in meeting the expectations of the House,\" the committee's report said.\u00a0", "\"Therefore, as a result of our deliberations, the Committee has begun work on changes we believe are necessary to the requirements of the Register of Members' Interests, in order to ensure the requirements more comprehensively reflect the intent and integrity of the Register.\"", "Under the current rules, politicians must declare gifts valued at more than $750 from official sources or a gift worth more than $300 when received from other official sources."]
